title: Strength and Stability for Longevity
content: Strength and stability are essential for longevity. Identifying problematic movement patterns and postures can help individuals relieve pain, avoid injury, and move better within all types of exercise. Movement is a trainable skill and there are suggestions for what people can add to their exercise routine to benefit their health and longevity.

title: Training Philosophy
content: The training philosophy is not partial to a single discipline. The approach draws from a variety of disciplines including: Functional Range Conditioning, Postural Restoration Institute, Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization.

title: Functional Range Conditioning and Scapular Mobility
content: Functional Range Conditioning (FRC) is primarily focused on getting to end range of motion and reinforcing that range by challenging it. The ability for the scapulae to glide across the rib cage vertically and horizontally is an important example of how FRC can be applied – this ability dictates capacity to move the shoulder and arm.

title: Postural Restoration Institute and Squat Assessment
content: The Postural Restoration Institute (PRI) is more oriented towards clinicians and is focused on patterns throughout the body. For example, the right side of the diaphragm is more compressed because the liver is on the right side, and this could be related to various restrictions throughout the body.

title: Connection Between Ribs and Breathing
content: Making sure that your breath can be wide and three-dimensional and easy is vital for creating good, efficient, coordinated movement. The ribs are your center of mass, and respiration is one of our constant stresses. We breath 20,000+ times per day – inefficiencies in breathing can therefore have large effects.

title: Role of Sitting and External Stress in Chronic Muscular Tension
content: Another constant stress is gravity — How are you working with or against gravity? If you’re not breathing well, if you’re not dealing with gravity well, that has a high cost. You’re having to hold this and you’re going to have that loading all of the time.

title: Effects of Sitting and Chronic Stress
content: Sitting a lot, especially in the same position, is not good for health. It's important to take breaks and change sitting position. Chronic stress, as opposed to acute distress, has a big impact on body tension and can cause sleep disturbances. Staring at a screen for long periods can also be stressful as it limits peripheral vision.

title: Importance of Footwear and Toe Use
content: Transitioning from a minimalist foot pattern to a heavily supported shoe can alter our attachment to the ground. Modern footwear can decrease one's ability to use their toes. The ability to use your toes is important as they dampen force. Modern shoes often squeeze your toes and minimize the use of your toes therefore your body becomes accustomed to not needing them.

title: Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization (DNS)
content: Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization (DNS) is based on a re-engineering of the development of movement patterns that occurs between three months of age and walking. It was originally developed to help kids with cerebral palsy, but is now used to help anyone with movement deficiencies.

title: Posture and Movement
content: Maintaining a single posture for too long is not healthy. It's important to move around and change postures often. Being too fixated on making things conscious leads to being less adaptive. A person needs to be reactive and adaptive to be able to respond to different changes in their environment.

title: Exercise and Movement Patterns
content: Lifting weights, split leg exercises, and dancing are beneficial for maintaining good movement capacity into old age. Balance declines with age and it’s better to address deficiencies sooner rather than later. Too much bracing with the abdominal muscles limits reflexiveness and adaptability and, in turn, resilience.

title: Benefits of Rowing
content: Rowing is a great way to promote backward movement and scapular mobility. It can help resolve back pain in many people. The starting position of rowing is similar to the start of a deadlift, where the posterior chain muscles are pre-loaded.

title: Concentric versus Eccentric Strength
content: An example of eccentric versus concentric strength that is extremely relevant to sports is accelerating and decelerating, respectively. Lack of eccentric strength can be equated to a sports car without brakes.

title: Eccentric Strength and Control
content: Eccentric strength promotes control, such as in the descent phase of a squat or lunge.

title: Flexibility and High-Intensity Interval Training
content: Flexibility is relative to the range of motion that can be controlled. Control and load tolerance are considered more important. High-intensity interval training should be done about 20% of the time, although most people need more Zone 2 exercise.

title: Training versus Playing Sports
content: Sports should not be used as a replacement for exercise. Training is about learning and paying attention, which can help in sports.

title: Activity during Childhood
content: Kids should spend more time playing and less time at desks and on screens. Kids who spend time playing and are involved with sports will have a better foundation of movement and will learn movement changes more easily. However, sport specialization and repetitive sports can hurt rather than help movement capacity.

title: Exercise Videos: PAILs and RAILs
content: PAILs and RAILs should be done at the end of a workout because they are neurologically challenging. Prior to starting a pail or rail, a stretch should be held for about two minutes. This is about how long it takes for neurological signaling to stabilize.

title: Hamstring Control
content: The purpose of the exercise is to learn how to activate the hamstrings with minimal activation of the abdominals. If done properly, breathing should feel normal and not restrained. The exercise is initiated with posterior pelvic tilt.

title: Deadlift
content: Prior to initiating the lift, a “wedge” is developed, which is basically a pre-loading of the appropriate muscles. It is important that the hips move back to maintain emphasis on the appropriate muscles.

title: Eccentric-Focused Step-Up
content: This exercise is just as much about positioning and posture (particularly the ribs) as it is about leg strengthening.

title: Breathing Assessment
content: Should feel ribs expanding and retracting. Reaching the arms up and protracting the scapulae helps promote proper rib positioning.

title: Assessments
content: Toe touch is more about how the spine segments than hamstring flexibility. Shifting weight back to the heels and a relatively flat lumbar spine indicate limited hamstring control.

title: Segmental Cat Cow and CARs
content: Segmental Cat Cow doubles as both an assessment and training for spinal segmentation. Segmental movement implies movement being spread across multiple vertebrae rather than movement being isolated to one area.

title: Tricep Extensions and Eccentric Split Squat
content: Tricep Extensions is an example of FRC and applying challenge at end range of motion. Eccentric Split Squat emphasizes on the control of the descent and bottom position. Restrained breathing and elevation of the shoulders during the ascent are indications of a lack of control.

title: Rowing
content: Rowing involves proper positioning and mechanics. Heels can be moderately elevated at the catch position, but with good sense of toes and forefoot. The catch position is similar to the deadlift wedge. Hips should open while pushing back from the catch position. Pull of the bar at the end of the motion should feel easy. During recovery, should feel a sense of being pulled in by the bar. Rowing can also be done single leg, which is particularly valuable for people with a leg injury.
